You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
If $x$ is a real number and $k$ is a nonnegative integer, recall that the binomial coefficient $\binom{x}{k}$ is defined by the formula
\[
  \binom{x}{k} = \frac{x(x - 1)(x - 2) \dots (x - k + 1)}{k!} \, .
\]Compute the value of
\[
  \frac{\binom{1/2}{2014} \cdot 4^{2014}}{\binom{4028}{2014}} \, .
\]

Using the definition of the binomial coefficient, we have
\begin{align*} \binom{1/2}{2014} &= \frac{\frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{1}{2} - 1 \right) \left( \frac{1}{2} - 2 \right) \dots \left( \frac{1}{2} - 2013 \right)}{2014!} \\ &= \frac{\frac{1}{2} \left( -\frac{1}{2} \right) \left( -\frac{3}{2} \right) \dots \left( -\frac{4025}{2} \right)}{2014!} \\ &= \frac{(-1)^{2013} \cdot \frac{1 \cdot 1 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \dots 4025}{2^{2014}}}{2014!} \\ &= \frac{(-1)^{2013} \cdot \frac{1 \cdot 1 \cdot 3 \cdot 5 \dots 4025}{2^{2014}}}{2014!} \\ &= \frac{(-1)^{2013} \cdot \frac{(2 \cdot 4 \cdot 6 \dots 4026)^{1/2}}{2^{2014}} \cdot \frac{1 \cdot 1 \cdot 3 \dots 4025}{2^{2014}}}{2014!} \\ &= \frac{(-1)^{2013} \cdot \frac{(4026!)^{1/2}}{2^{2014}} \cdot \frac{(2 \cdot 4 \cdot 6 \dots 4026)^{1/2}}{2^{2014}}}{2014!} \\ &= \frac{(-1)^{2013} \cdot \frac{\prod_{k = 1}^{2014} (2k-1)}{2^{2014}}}{2014!} \end{align*} 
Then
\begin{align*} \binom{1/2}{2014} &= \frac{(-1)^{2013} \prod_{j=1}^{2014} (2j-1)}{2^{2014} 2014!} \\ &= \frac{(-1)^{2013} \prod_{j=1}^{2014} (2j-1)}{2^{2014} 2014!} \end{align*} 
The expression
$$ \frac{\binom{1/2}{2014} 4^{2014}}{\binom{4028}{2014}} = \frac{(-1)^{2013} 2^{2 \cdot 2014} \prod_{j=1}^{2014} (2j-1) / 2^{2014} 2014!}{4028 \dots 2015 / 2014!} $$
The numerator becomes
\begin{align*} \frac{(-1)^{2013} 4^{2014} \prod_{j=1}^{2014} (2j-1)}{2^{2014} 2014!} = \frac{(-1)^{2013} 2^{2(2014)} \prod_{j=1}^{2014} (2j-1)}{2^{2014} 2014!} = \frac{(-1)^{2013} 2^{2014} \prod_{j=1}^{2014} (2j-1)}{2014!} \end{align*} 
By Lucas' theorem
Final Answer: $\boxed{1}$
